title: 111_s2784
content: The text chunk is about the permanent extension of the estate tax as it was in effect in 2009. The text chunk discusses amendments to the unified credit against gift tax and estate tax, increasing the exclusion equivalent to $3,500,000. The applicable exclusion amount for estate tax purposes is $3,500,000, with an inflation adjustment for decedents after 2010. The estate tax exclusion amount is $3,500,000 with an inflation adjustment for decedents after 2010. Any adjusted amount not a multiple of $10,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. The maximum estate tax rate is equal to 45 percent. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the imposition and rate of tax. The estate tax credit amount is determined based on the applicable exclusion amount. For nonresident decedents, the credit cannot be less than a proportion based on the value of their gross estate in the United States. The decedent's entire gross estate is subject to estate and gift taxes, with modifications made to reflect differences in unified credit resulting from different tax rates. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to adjust the computation of tax based on subsection (g) modifications. The decedent's gross estate is subject to estate and gift taxes, with adjustments for unified credit due to varying tax rates. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to calculate tax based on subsection (g) modifications, using rates at the decedent's death for gift tax computation and credit allowance. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to calculate tax based on modifications for estate and gift taxes. The changes include using current tax rates for gift tax computation and credit allowance, effective for decedents dying after December 31, 2009. Additionally, certain provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 are repealed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals certain provisions and amendments related to titles V and sections 511 and 521. The code is to be applied as if these provisions had never been enacted. Additionally, the sunset provision of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is amended to exclude title V after December 31, 2010. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals sections 2011, 2057, and 2604. Tables related to these sections are also amended to reflect the repeal. SEC. 2. The deceased spousal unused exclusion amount is the excess of the deceased spouse's basic exclusion amount over the tentative tax amount on their estate. This amount can be transferred to the surviving spouse, but an election is required. The surviving spouse cannot use the deceased spouse's exclusion amount without the executor filing an estate tax return and making an irrevocable election. No election can be made if the return is filed after the deadline. The IRS can examine a deceased spouse's return to determine the unused exclusion amount. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the applicable credit amount will apply to estates of decedents dying, generation-skipping transfers, and gifts made after December 31, 2009. The Senate believes that any decrease in Federal revenues from this Act should be fully offset.
